Oven Roasted Prime Rib

Jump to Recipe

If you're looking to impress your family or guests with a show-stopping centerpiece at your next dinner, look no further than this Oven Roasted Prime Rib recipe. Known for its rich flavor and tender, juicy texture, prime rib is the ultimate choice for special occasions, holiday feasts, or a luxurious weekend dinner. This recipe guides you through the simple yet effective steps to achieve a perfectly roasted prime rib, seasoned with aromatic garlic and onion powder, and enhanced with fresh rosemary and thyme. With just a few essential ingredients and some careful roasting, you can create a mouthwatering dish that is sure to leave everyone asking for seconds. Whether you're a novice in the kitchen or a seasoned chef, mastering this prime rib recipe will elevate your culinary skills and satisfy even the most discerning palates. Let's dive into the details and get ready to roast!

Ingredients

prime rib roast

Look for a well-marbled roast, as the fat will enhance flavor and juiciness. If you can't find prime rib, a ribeye roast can be a good substitute. Make sure to bring the roast to room temperature before cooking for even cooking.

garlic powder

Garlic powder is great for even distribution of garlic flavor. If you prefer fresh garlic, use about 4-6 cloves, minced, but reduce the amount of salt slightly since fresh garlic can add moisture.

onion powder

Onion powder provides a subtle sweetness and depth. If you don't have onion powder, finely minced fresh onion (about 1/4 cup) can be used, but be aware it may add moisture.

salt

Kosher salt is best for seasoning meat as it adheres well. If using table salt, reduce the amount slightly since it is finer and saltier in taste. Consider using a herb-infused salt for additional flavor.

black pepper

Freshly ground black pepper has a stronger flavor than pre-ground. For a more complex flavor, consider using a mix of black, white, and even pink peppercorns.

olive oil

Extra virgin olive oil will add a nice flavor. If you're looking for a higher smoke point, consider using grapeseed or avocado oil instead.

fresh rosemary

Fresh rosemary adds a wonderful aromatic flavor. If you don’t have fresh, you can use dried rosemary, but reduce the amount to about 1 tsp as it is more concentrated.

fresh thyme

Thyme complements beef beautifully. If fresh isn’t available, use 1 tsp of dried thyme. For a different flavor profile, consider adding some fresh oregano.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Preheat the Oven

    Set your oven to 450°F (232°C) to ensure it's hot enough to create a nice crust on the prime rib.

  • Step 2: Prepare the Seasoning Mix

    In a small bowl, combine 2 tsp of garlic powder, 2 tsp of onion powder, 2 tbsp of salt, and 2 tsp of black pepper. Mix well to ensure even distribution.

  • Step 3: Prepare the Prime Rib Roast

    Rub the 5 lbs prime rib roast with 2 tbsp of olive oil. This not only helps the seasoning stick but also contributes to a beautiful crust.

  • Step 4: Apply the Seasoning

    Sprinkle the seasoning mixture evenly over the entire roast. Make sure to cover all sides for maximum flavor.

  • Step 5: Add Fresh Herbs

    Place the roast on a rack in a roasting pan with the bone side down. Insert 2 sprigs of fresh rosemary and 2 sprigs of fresh thyme around the roast for added flavor.

  • Step 6: Initial Roasting

    Roast in the preheated oven for 20 minutes. This high heat will help create a delicious crust.

  • Step 7: Lower the Temperature

    After 20 minutes, reduce the oven temperature to 325°F (163°C). Continue roasting for about 1.5 hours or until the internal temperature reaches 130°F (54°C) for medium-rare.

  • Step 8: Rest the Roast

    Remove the roast from the oven and let it rest for 20 minutes before slicing. This step is crucial as it allows the juices to redistribute, resulting in a juicy and tender roast.

Frequently Asked Questions

What should I do if I don't have a roasting pan?

If you don't have a roasting pan, you can use a baking dish or a cast-iron skillet. Place a wire rack inside the dish to elevate the roast, allowing air to circulate and ensuring even cooking.

How can I tell when the prime rib is done cooking?

The best way to check if your prime rib is done is by using a meat thermometer. For medium-rare, aim for an internal temperature of 130°F (54°C). Remember that the temperature will rise a bit while resting.

Why is resting the meat important?

Resting the meat is crucial because it allows the juices to redistribute throughout the roast. If you slice it right away, the juices will run out, making the meat dry.

What can I serve with prime rib?

Prime rib pairs beautifully with sides like roasted vegetables, mashed potatoes, or a fresh salad. You can also serve it with horseradish sauce or a rich gravy.

Can I use dried herbs instead of fresh?

Yes, you can use dried herbs if fresh aren't available. Use about one-third of the amount since dried herbs are more concentrated. For this recipe, use 1 tsp of dried rosemary and 1 tsp of dried thyme.

What if I want to cook it differently, like in a slow cooker?

You can certainly cook prime rib in a slow cooker! Season it the same way, then place it in the slow cooker with a bit of beef broth. Cook on low for about 6-8 hours until tender.

How do I store leftover prime rib?

To store leftover prime rib, wrap it tightly in plastic wrap or aluminum foil and place it in the refrigerator. It will stay fresh for about 3-4 days. You can also freeze it for longer storage.

What should I do if I overcook the prime rib?

If you overcook the prime rib, try slicing it thinly and serving it with gravy or sauce to help keep it moist. Adding a flavorful side can also enhance the overall meal.

Is it necessary to marinate the prime rib?

Marinating is not necessary for prime rib, as this cut is naturally tender and flavorful. The seasoning rub will enhance its taste without the need for marinating.

How do I ensure the seasoning sticks to the meat?

Rubbing the roast with olive oil before applying the seasoning helps it stick better. The oil creates a nice surface for the spices to adhere to.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This dish is inherently gluten-free and can be suitable for those on a low-carb or keto diet, given its focus on meat and herbs. For a dairy-free option, ensure that any sides or sauces do not contain dairy. If you're catering to a larger group with varied dietary preferences, consider offering a vegetarian option such as a stuffed portobello mushroom or a hearty vegetable lasagna as an alternative.

Pairings

For an exquisite dining experience, pair the Oven Roasted Prime Rib with a robust red wine such as a Cabernet Sauvignon or a Merlot. These wines complement the rich flavors of the beef beautifully. Additionally, consider serving it alongside classic steakhouse sides like creamy mashed potatoes, garlic sautéed green beans, or a fresh arugula salad with shaved Parmesan. For a special touch, add a horseradish cream sauce or chimichurri for dipping.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the prime rib on a large, rustic wooden board or an elegant platter for a stunning presentation. Slice the roast into thick, juicy pieces and fan them out for visual appeal. Garnish with herbs (like fresh rosemary and thyme) and serve with the sides arranged artfully around the beef. Use warm serving dishes to keep everything at the ideal temperature. Consider offering a selection of mustards and sauces on the side for guests to customize their plates.

Oven Roasted Prime Rib

150 min
$100
800 kcal
Difficulty: 40%
Servings: 8

Dietary Tags:

Gluten-FreePaleo

Cuisine:

American

Course:

Main Course

Tags:

beefroastholidaymain course

Description

A succulent and tender prime rib roast, seasoned to perfection and slow-cooked for an incredible flavor.

Ingredients

  • prime rib roast: 5 lbs
  • garlic powder: 2 tsp
  • onion powder: 2 tsp
  • salt: 2 tbsp
  • black pepper: 2 tsp
  • olive oil: 2 tbsp
  • fresh rosemary: 2 sprigs
  • fresh thyme: 2 sprigs
